choices.text: Bakri balloon - compression of the uterine walls from inside
Sengstaken blakemore tube - compression of the bleeding areas of uterus from outside cavity
Bakri balloon - compression of the bleeding areas of uterus from outside cavity
Sengstaken blakemore tube - compression of the uterine walls from inside

questions.text: Identify the method of management of PPH and identify the mechanism of action of the same:
questions.solution:
Balloon tamponade for the management of PPH :

These include condom catheter, Sengstaken Blakemore esophageal balloon and Bakri balloon. They externally compress the site of hemorrhage by causing hydrostatic pressure upon the uterine vessels to control bleeding.

Bakri balloon is the one that has been most often used. It is elastic silicone balloon-shaped device that connects with a catheter that allows the flow of saline in to the device. This balloon has a maximum recommended volume of 500 mL and can be inserted transvaginal or transabdominal depending on the delivery route. The balloon is filled with saline which causes distention of the device walls, compressing the bleeding area, stopping the hemorrhage.

Reference : D.C. Dutta textbook of obstetrics 9/edition, chapter 28, page number:389

choices.text: Place an incision, drain the swelling and explore the bleeders
Wait and watch as the condition is self limiting

questions.text: A patient delivered vaginally. The resident doctor after 2 hours of delivery noted the patient to have diaphoresis, with pulse rate of 130/min and BP of 100/70 mmhg. She was taken for exploration. Her uterus was contracted and the per vaginal examination revealed no active bleeding per vaginum. A tense swelling was noted on the right lateral wall of vagina which was tender. What could be the management for the patient?
questions.solution:
The cause of altered vitals is PPH due to a vaginal hematoma. Since the patient is hemodynamically unstable, the doctor cannot wait and watch. Rather urgent exploration of bleeder needs to be done after incision and drainage of hematoma.

As the cause of PPH is traumatic and not atonic, there is no role of oxytocin or uterine massage.

Reference : D.C. Dutta textbook of obstetrics 9/edition, chapter 29, page number:399

choices.text: The procedure is done in primigravida patients routinely die to rigid perineum
Lateral incision is preferred method to prevent extension into the anal canal
The procedure is done when the head is on perineum and does not recede back with relaxation
The ischiocavernosus muscle is cut in the procedure

questions.text: What is correct about the procedure for which the following instrument is used ?
questions.solution:
The procedure is done when the head is on perineum and does not recede back with relaxation i.e Crowning

Explanation: The instrument is episiotomy scissors with which episiotomy is performed.

Important points:

  • Surgical incision made on perineum to increase diameter of vulva to deliver the baby
  • It is second degree perineal tear
  • It is not done routinely in labour
  • Indications : Rigid inelastic perineum, macrosomia, face to pubis delivery, breech, shoulder dystocia, forceps, ventouse delivery
  • Ideal time of incision is crowning of head on perineum
  • Mediolateral is the best incision. Medial incision can lead to 3rd or 4th degree perineal tear.(Option C)

Following are the 2 main types of episiotomy:

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy are:

  1. Levator Ani(Pubococcygeus and Iliococcygeus), NOT Ischiocavernosus(Option D)
  2. Superficial and deep transverse perinei
  3. Bulbospongiosus
  4. Pudendal nerves and vessels
  5. Posterior vaginal wall
  6. Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Reference : D.C. Dutta textbook of obstetrics 9/edition, chapter 37, page& number:528

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute indication of the following incision type during cesarean section ?
questions.solution:
The incision is a classical cesarean incision. The only absolute indication for classical incision is carcinoma cervix. In all other cases, lower segment c section (LSCS) incision in placed

Reference : D.C. Dutta textbook of obstetrics 9/edition, chapter 23. page number:307

choices.text: There is a high risk of facial nerve palsy with the use if the device
It is preferred to cut short the second stage of labour in cases of maternal heart disease
It is applied at a point 3 cm anterior to posterior fontanelle

questions.text: What is not true about the use of the following instrument ?
questions.solution:
Vacuum delivery :

  • Initial pressure 0.2 kg/cm3
  • Maximum pressure 0.8 kg/cm3(Option A)
  • The vacuum is applied at flexion point 3 cm anterior to posterior fontanelle and 6 cm posterior to anterior fontanelle (Option D)
  • Vacuum cannot be applied to presentation other than vertex presentation(occipito anterior or occipito posterior)
  • Indications :
    • Maternal exhaustion
    • Prolonged second stage labour
    • Maternal heart disease(Option C)
  • Contraindications :
    • Contracted pelvis
    • Osteogenesis imperfecta
    • Known coagulopathy in fetus
    • Preterm babies
    • Fetal distress
  • Complications :
    • Cephalhematoma
    • Subgaleal hematoma
    • Retinal nerve injury
    • Sixth nerve injury
  • Maximum three attempts can be given to pull the fetus after which fetus to be delivered by c section

Reference : D.C. Dutta textbook of obstetrics 9/edition, chapter 27, page number:531

choices.text: Rupture uterus which cannot be repaired

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for obstetric/cesarean hysterectomy ?
questions.solution:
Couvellaire uterus is not an indication for hysterectomy. It may lead to hysterectomy only if associated with PPH

Indications of obstetric hysterectomy

  1. Uterine atony leading to PPH
  2. Placenta accreta spectrum
  3. Uterine extension
  4. Uterine rupture
  5. Cervical laceration
  6. Leiomyoma
  7. Invasive cervical cancer
  8. Ovarian neoplasia

Reference : J.B. Sharma textbook of obstetrics 3/edition, chapter 42, page number:720

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for spontaneous preterm labour?
questions.solution:
Risk factors for spontaneous pre term labour :

Pre eclampsia is more commonly associated with induced pre term labour rather than spontaneous preterm labour(Option C ruled out)

All vaginitis cause pre term labour except candida (Option A ruled out) 

Reference: J.B. Sharma obstetrics 3/edition, page number:493.

questions.solution:
Antibiotic prophylaxis in PPROM:

DOC is macrolides (azithromycin or erythromycin)

Other drug is amoxicillin. Clavulinic acid is not added to amoxicillin as clavulinic acid is suspected to cause NEC in such neonates

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida woman at 40 weeks of gestation is in the second stage of labor. Despite adequate contractions and maternal effort, the fetal head remains at +2 station for an extended period. The fetal heart rate tracing shows non-reassuring patterns, and the decision is made to proceed with an instrumental delivery using forceps to expedite the delivery. The procedure is successful, and a healthy baby is delivered. Which maternal complication is most commonly associated with the use of forceps in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Forceps delivery increases the risk of severe perineal tears, especially third or fourth-degree tears, due to the mechanical forces applied during the procedure to assist in the delivery of the baby.

Following are the common complications of ventouse and forceps delivery:

Explanation:

Option A: Uterine rupture

Uterine rupture is a serious but rare complication typically associated with a history of uterine surgery, such as a previous cesarean section, or with excessive uterine contractions, such as those from oxytocin misuse. It is not commonly associated with forceps delivery, especially in a primigravida without prior uterine surgery or scar.

Option B: Postpartum hemorrhage

Postpartum hemorrhage can occur following any delivery, including those with instrumental assistance, but it is not the most common complication specific to forceps use. While trauma from forceps can contribute to bleeding, postpartum hemorrhage is more commonly due to uterine atony, retained placenta, or coagulopathy, rather than the direct effect of forceps application.

Option C: Third or fourth-degree perineal tears

Third or fourth-degree perineal tears, which involve the anal sphincter complex, are the most common maternal complications associated with forceps delivery. The use of forceps can increase the risk of significant perineal trauma due to the mechanical force exerted on the perineum and surrounding tissues during extraction. Proper technique and protective measures can reduce but not eliminate this risk.

Option D: Deep vein thrombosis

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is not specifically associated with forceps delivery. It is more related to immobility, hypercoagulability, and endothelial damage, which can occur in any postpartum period, regardless of the delivery method. The risk of DVT is not increased specifically by the use of forceps.

Reference: Dutta's Obstetrics 9th edition, Page number. 659

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for a patient with prolonged latent phase of labor?
questions.solution:
Option C: Provide hydration and rest

Providing hydration and rest is the most appropriate initial management for prolonged latent phase of labor. Ensuring adequate hydration and rest can help alleviate maternal fatigue, reduce stress, and potentially facilitate the progression of labor. It is a conservative and non-invasive approach that allows for the latent phase to naturally transition into the active phase.

Option A: Administer intravenous oxytocin

While oxytocin is commonly used to augment labor in cases of labor dystocia, it is not the first-line management for a prolonged latent phase of labor. The latent phase can often be managed conservatively with rest and hydration, allowing the cervix to continue effacing and dilating. Oxytocin may be considered later if active labor does not progress after initial conservative measures.

Option B: Perform immediate cesarean section

Immediate cesarean section is not appropriate as an initial management step for a prolonged latent phase of labor. Cesarean delivery is typically reserved for cases of failed induction, fetal distress, or other obstetric complications. The latent phase can often be prolonged without indicating immediate surgical intervention, especially if the mother and fetus are stable.

Option D: Apply fetal scalp electrode

Applying a fetal scalp electrode is used for internal monitoring of the fetal heart rate, typically when external monitoring is inadequate or there is a concern for fetal distress. It is not a management strategy for a prolonged latent phase of labor and does not address the progression of labor.

Reference: Dutta's Obstetrics 9th edition, Page number. 463

questions.text: Rate of involution of uterus is:
questions.solution:
The average rate of uterine involution is approximately 1.25 cm per day.

Rate of Uterine Involution

  • Immediately after delivery: Uterus is at the level of the umbilicus.
  • Day 1 postpartum: Fundus is approximately 1.25 cm below the umbilicus.
  • Daily reduction: The fundus descends about 1.25 cm per day.
  • End of 1 week: Fundus is typically midway between the umbilicus and the pubic symphysis.
  • End of 2 weeks: Uterus is no longer palpable abdominally.
  • By 6 weeks: Uterus returns to its non-pregnant size (around 60-80 grams).

This steady descent continues until the uterus reaches its normal size and position by about 6 weeks postpartum. Factors like breastfeeding (which increases oxytocin release), parity, and presence of complications can influence this rate.

Reference: Dutta's Obstetrics 9th edition, Page number. 169-170
